Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Mining Information Propagation on the Web

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Real-time information is a fundamental emerging issue in the creation
and management of Web content. Increasingly, rather than consulting
relatively static sources that are indexed on a periodic basis,
people refer to information on news sites, blogs, social-networking
sites, and Twitter feeds that change dynamically and spread rapidly.
This project will study how information content varies over time, how
it is transmitted through underlying social networks, and how its
recipients assemble it into larger units. The project will explore
new techniques for addressing these issues, based on novel methods
for tracking, analyzing, and presenting information that evolves and
spreads rapidly over time. The resulting approach aims to transform
important aspects of the ways in which real-time information on the
Web is handled.

First the fundamental units of information that spread through the
underlying information networks will be identified. From a set of
nearly 1 billion news media articles and blog posts (approx. 6TB of
data), and a collection of 500 million tweets from Twitter, small
(generally textual) units of information will be identified that
remain relatively stable as they spread through the Web. The
temporal variation within these basic units will be analyzed and
modeled. This modeling will include connections with biological
models of epidemics, as well as new frameworks that exploit the
fundamental differences between biological and social contagion.
Finally, the temporal variation will be related to network-level
models for the diffusion of this information. Generally, the actual
networks on which real-time information spreads cannot be directly
observed, nor can the influence of any particular node in the network
be directly measured. Therefore, the project will develop machine-
learning techniques that infer these hidden networks and unobserved
levels of influence.

For more information see the project web site at:
http://snap.stanford.edu/proj/mipro

POR.DRECONTENT:
The sharing of information on-line has become a fundamental part of how people stay informed, learn about current events, and interact with one another. Despite the central role that these processes play in everyday life, they are not well understood, and the systems to support rich sharing of information are at a correspondingly early stage in their development. 

The project pursued several approaches in seeking to transform the field's understanding of the spread of information. Its intellectual merit was based on both the development of formal models for the spread of information, and on a set of design principles for working with systems in which information is shared through a network. To pursue these goals, the project synthesized techniques in computing with ideas originating in statistics, sociology, and linguistics. 

The project's main contributions are as follows. It provided a method for characterizing ``memorable'' language to help identify textual information that was more likely to be shared and persist; via a machine-learning analysis, memorable language was found to be distinctive in its choice of words, but typical in its part-of-speech composition. The project developed new models for the spread of information and behavior in a social network; these models were based on a formulation in which individuals make strategic choices about their behavior to balance internal preferences with the behavior of others in the network. And the project also developed new methods for performing randomized experiments in networks: when people in a social network influence each other's behavior, it is hard to test an effect on one person in isolation, and so this new approach to experimentation divides up the network so that different effects can be tested in different clusters. 

The project has had several broader impacts. Graduate students trained as part of the project have contributed to the further development of these ideas both in academia and also in industry. The project's results on memorability of language and randomized experiments with network effects have been explored for possible applications in the context of Facebook. And ideas from the project have informed the development of educational material at the introductory undergraduate level, including most recently a massive open on-line course.
